Ascension: Rise to Power

Chandragupta Maurya is called the 'Liberator of India' for freeing the country from the misrule of the Nandas and the dominance of the Greeks. Under the guidance of his guru, the brilliant strategist Chanakya, he overthrew Dhanananda and captured Pataliputra in 322 BCE.

'Liberator of India'Founder of the Mauryan Empire
тЪФя╕П
Conquests and Diplomacy
  • Liberation of the Northwest: After coming to power, he liberated the territories conquered by Alexander from the Greek governors.
  • War with Seleucus Nicator (c. 305 BCE): He defeated Seleucus. A treaty was signed wherein Seleucus ceded four provinces - Herat, Kandahar, Kabul, and Balochistan - to Chandragupta, who in return gifted 500 war elephants. A marital alliance was also established, and Seleucus sent his ambassador, Megasthenes, to Chandragupta's court.
Defeated Seleucus Nicator, Alexander's General
ЁЯУЬ
Reign and Administration

He built a vast empire stretching from the Himalayas in the north to Northern Karnataka in the south, and from Bengal in the east to the Hindu Kush mountains in the west.

ЁЯМ╕
Faith and Philosophy

According to Jain tradition, he embraced Jainism towards the end of his life and accompanied the Jain saint Bhadrabahu to Shravanabelagola (Karnataka), where he ended his life through Sallekhana.
